messages.content: A boat repairman notices that boats caught in storms often come back with damage on the front of their hulls but never on the back. He advises his clients to reinforce the front of their boats to increase their chances to survive stormy weather. Is he correct in his advice ?

his is an example of risk parity, a concept in finance and risk management. Although the front of a boat is exposed to the elements more than the back, the back of the boat is where the rudder and the propulsion equipment is located. If a storm were to approach the boat from the rear, the boat owner would have the option of tacking (swinging the rudder to change the direction of movement of the boat) or he could reduce engine power. Reducing engine power in a storm would increase the chance of being swamped. Therefore, it is safer to reinforce the front of the boat.
What, if anything, can we say about the fact that boats never come back with damage on the back ?

is suggests that the risk of being swamped by the rear is not the same for the front as it is for the back. It is possible that the front is more exposed to natural hazards such as rough seas, while the back is more exposed to human errors such as hitting rocks.
Isn't this a case of survivor bias ?

vivor bias is a concept in statistics. It describes the situation where only observations of a phenomenon that have "survived" to examine are collected and reported. In this example, only observations of boats that came back with damage on the front are reported to the boat owner. There may be other observations of boats that were caught in storms that had no damage on the front but did have damage on the back, which was not reported. If we collected and analyzed all observations (regardless of the location of damage), we would conclude that the risk of being swamped is not the same for the front as it is for the back.
